question: Which Latin American pop provocateur, known for her flamboyant persona and legal controversies in the early 2000s, released a song whose title translates roughly as 'everyone stares at me'?
llm_answer: Gloria Trevi, the Mexican pop provocateur who spent nearly five years in prison in the early 2000s on (later-dismissed) charges, released the 2006 single “Todos Me Miran” (“Everyone Looks at Me”).

context.text: "Todos Me Miran" (" Everyone looks at me ") is a song by the Mexican artist Gloria Trevi . Released as a single in 2006, the song peaked at number 18 on the Billboard Latin Pop Songs chart and number 32 on the Hot Latin Songs chart. It was featured on Trevi's 2006 live album La Trayectoria . The song, as interpreted in the music video, is about a young man who dares to crossdress in spite of society's opinions. The song became a club anthem that confirmed Trevi's status as a gay icon . With this new production Gloria once again entered the international music charts. It was an unparalleled success throughout Latin America, the United States, Mexico and returned her to the popularity she had established in the nineties in the European region, climbing to the top positions in countries such as Croatia, Belgium, Sweden, Germany, Romania, Italy and France and reaffirming her status as a consecrated star in her strongest market in that continent, Spain. Todos me miran became her biggest international hit since Pelo suelto, and is also considered her most representative song and one of the songs responsible for building Spanish pop music during the 2000s, opening the doors to the foreign market for what would become the new musical generations. Today it is one of the biggest references in Latin pop culture worldwide and established Gloria as the biggest Spanish-speaking LGBT Icon. The song was presented in Premios lo Nuestro 2007 as the opening act for the ceremony and winner Video of the Year. Gloria revisited the ceremony for the first time since 1993. Charts Commercial performance The song was released as the first single of what would be Gloria's first DVD recording titled La Trajectoria. It was distributed as a single CD and also on Digital Download worldwide. Gloria de los Ángeles Treviño Ruiz (born February 15, 1968), known professionally as Gloria Trevi , is a Mexican singer-songwriter. She is one of the best-selling Latin music artists in history, having sold over 20 million records worldwide. Trevi is known for her emotional lyrics, performances, and lasting influence on Latin music , being dubbed the " Mexican Queen of Pop " by Rolling Stone . She is also known for the media coverage surrounding the Trevi–Andrade scandal, involving sexual abuse and forced labour led by her former manager - producer Sergio Andrade. At 15, she moved to Mexico City to study performing arts at Televisa 's CEA . In 1984, she met record producer Sergio Andrade, who added her to his girl group project Boquitas Pintadas, which disbanded after one unsuccessful album the same year. Trevi later tracked down Andrade and recorded a demo in Los Angeles, which led to her debut album ¿Qué Hago Aquí? (1989), containing her breakthrough single "Dr. Psiquiatra" that rose her to fame. In the 1990s, Trevi released the albums— Tu Ángel de la Guarda (1991), Me Siento Tan Sola (1992), Más Turbada Que Nunca (1994), and Si Me Llevas Contigo (1995)—featuring hits like "Pelo Suelto", "Zapatos Viejos", and "Con los Ojos Cerrados", cementing her status as a sex symbol and pop icon and bringing her international fame. In 1997, Trevi retired from public life with Andrade. During this period, a complaint against her, Sergio Andrade, and other women was filed in Chihuahua involving allegations of sexual abuse, corruption of minors, and forced labor, following the disappearance of 17-year-old Karina Yapor and other young women. In January 2000, they were arrested in Rio de Janeiro . She spent nearly five years in pre-trial detention , first in Brazil and then following her extradition to Mexico. Finally, in 2004, Trevi and two other women were tried and acquitted , while Andrade was convicted. Her life and career have been dramatized in the 2014 biopic Gloria and the 2023 TV series Gloria Trevi: Ellas soy yo . Trevi resumed her career with four number-one albums on the Billboard Top Latin Albums chart, including Gloria (2011) and El Amor (2015). She also scored success with singles such as " Todos Me Miran ", " Cinco Minutos ", and "No Querías Lastimarme". " What the Water Gave Me " is a song by English indie rock band Florence and the Machine from their second studio album, Ceremonials (2011). The song was written by lead singer Florence Welch and Francis "Eg" White , and produced by Paul Epworth . It was released on 23 August 2011 as the first promotional single from Ceremonials . After the band performed the song in Berkeley, California , on 12 June 2011, the studio version premiered on Florence and the Machine's official website. Welch decided to name the song "What the Water Gave Me" after seeing the 1938 Frida Kahlo painting of the same name . During an interview, she confirmed that the song was inspired by English writer Virginia Woolf . "What the Water Gave Me" is a pop , pop rock and soul song performed in tempo of 124 beats per minute. It incorporates several instruments into its composition, most notably harps and guitar . The accompanying music video for the song was filmed at Abbey Road Studios and it showed the band recording and singing the song. Upon its release, the song made its way into several chart most notably at number 24 on the UK Singles Chart . It also became the second song by Florence and the Machine which charted on the US Billboard Hot 100 . Background The song was recorded at Abbey Road Studios in London "What the Water Gave Me" was written by Florence Welch and Francis "Eg" White and produced by Paul Epworth . It was recorded in London at Abbey Road Studios . The song was debuted by Florence and the Machine during a live show in Berkeley, California on 12 June 2011. After that, the band added the song to the set list of their tour, Lungs Tour and on 23 August 2011 the album version of the song premiered on Florence and the Machine ' s official website. Welch elaborated on the title and meaning of the song: "It's a song for the water, because in music and art what I'm really interested in are the things that are overwhelming. The ocean seems to me to be nature's great overwhelmer. When I was writing this song I was thinking a lot about all those people who've lost their lives in vain attempts to save their loved ones from drowning. It's about water in all forms and all bodies. It's about a lot of things; Virginia Woolf creeps into it, and of course Frida Kahlo , whose painfully beautiful painting gave me the title". During an interview with NME , Welch revealed how she looked in Frida Kahlo painting by saying, "At lot of the time when I'm writing, things will just appear. I was writing the song and this book on symbolism was lying around, and it had the painting in it. It's nice to mix the ordinary with extraordinary". " Never Let Me Go " is a song by English indie rock band Florence and the Machine from their second studio album, Ceremonials (2011). The song was written by Florence Welch and Paul Epworth while production was handled by Epworth. Island Records released the song as the third single from the album on 30 March 2012. The band first premiered the song during one of their concerts before the release of the album on 15 October 2011. A Clams Casino remix of the song was placed on the 12" white vinyl single which was available for pre-order on 22 March 2012. Musically, "Never Let Me Go" is a downtempo baroque pop and indie pop ballad in the key of A major completed with piano and drums while backing vocals repeatedly sing "never let me go" throughout the song. Many critics noted similarities between the song's composition and materials by other artists including Enya , Evanescence and Ryan Tedder -produced songs. The song received acclaim by critics who praised Welch's vocals and its balladry nature. Commercially, "Never Let Me Go" reached the top 10 in Israel and Australia, where it has been certified multi-platinum. An accompanying music video for the song was released online on 8 March 2012. It was directed by Tabitha Denholm and stars actor Jamie Campbell Bower , who plays Welch's love interest. The video features the pair together skating and shots of a dirty water trickling down Welch's face and hands are shown. Upon the release of the video, critics praised Welch's gothic look and the video's dark atmosphere. Florence and the Machine added the song to the set list of their second worldwide Ceremonials Tour (2011–2012) where the song was performed during the encore of the concerts along with " No Light, No Light ". Background and release "Never Let Me Go" was written by Florence Welch , Paul Epworth , and Kid Harpoon while production was handled by Epworth. Florence and the Machine premiered "Never Let Me Go" along with two other songs from the album, " Spectrum " and "Heartlines" as part of their set list at New York's Creators Project on 15 October 2011, two weeks before the release of the album. Speaking about the song, Welch told Digital Spy , "The gospel thing comes from my obsession with hymns. I'm drawn to anything that has a hymnal quality, be it Spiritualized or dusty old albums by Georgian choirs." Island Records released "Never Let Me Go" as the third single from the album on 2 April 2012. A Clams Casino remix of the song was placed on the 12" white vinyl single which was available for pre-order on 22 March 2012. **Title**: John Cena’s Entrance Theme

**Summary**:  
“The Time Is Now” is John Cena’s best-known entrance theme, used in WWE from 2005 through his 2025 retirement match. Recorded with his cousin Marc “Trademarc” Predka and producer Jake One, the track samples M.O.P.’s “Ante Up,” prompting a short-lived 2008 lawsuit that was later dropped. Released as the lead single from Cena’s debut album *You Can’t See Me*, the song also became an Internet meme and anchors Cena’s rapper-turned-superstar persona that evolved from early-2000s freestyle segments on *SmackDown*.

**Keywords**:  
John Cena, WWE entrance theme, The Time Is Now, You Can’t See Me, Ante Up sampling

**Title**: Gloria Trevi’s “Todos Me Miran” Phenomenon  

**Summary**:  
“Todos Me Miran” became Gloria Trevi’s signature 2006 comeback hit, celebrating gender-nonconforming identity and turning into an LGBT anthem across Latin America, the U.S., and Europe. Despite scant U.S. radio support, the single logged 35+ weeks on Billboard Latin charts, topped Monitor Latino tallies in eight countries, and earned gold in Mexico for 75 k copies. In Spain it dominated the Los 40 network for five weeks, sold 95 k digital/polyphonic units, and turned Trevi into “Queen” of Gran Canaria Pride. The track collected nominations at Premios lo Nuestro, Premios Oye!, and Los 40 Music Awards, while charting from Sweden (No. 12) to Italy (No. 68) and Brazil (No. 2), re-establishing Trevi as the biggest Spanish-speaking gay icon of the 2000s.  

**Keywords**:  
Todos Me Miran, Gloria Trevi, LGBT anthem, Latin pop success, international charts

**Title**: Gloria Trevi Career & Controversy

**Summary**: Gloria Trevi is a prolific Mexican pop-rock singer whose discography spans from 1989’s *¿Qué Hago Aquí?* to the upcoming 2025 album *El Vuelo*, punctuated by frequent world tours. Beyond chart success, her career was overshadowed by a 2000 arrest in Brazil on charges of corrupting minors; she spent four years and eight months in prison before being cleared for lack of evidence in 2004. In 2023 Trevi filed her own lawsuit against former manager Sergio Andrade for sexual abuse, re-framing her earlier legal battles.

**Title**: Gloria Trevi Pop Legacy

**Summary**:  
Gloria Trevi, dubbed the “Mexican Queen of Pop,” rose from 1989’s breakout hit “Dr. Psiquiatra” to become one of Latin music’s best-selling artists, selling 20 million-plus records and charting global anthems like “Pelo Suelto” and “Cinco Minutos.” After a mid-’90s retirement and highly publicized legal battles, she rebounded with chart-topping albums *Una Rosa Blu*, *Gloria*, *El Amor*, and the collaborative *Versus*, earning BMI and Billboard honors plus a 2018 Latin Songwriters Hall of Fame induction. Her career—marked by provocative lyrics, alter-ego concepts, and record-breaking tours—cements her status as a resilient icon who shaped modern Latin pop.

**Title**: "Never Let Me Go" Song Profile  

**Summary**:  
"Never Let Me Go" is a downtempo baroque-pop ballad by Florence and the Machine, released as the third single from their 2011 album *Ceremonials*. Co-written by Florence Welch and Paul Epworth, the track pairs piano and thudding drums with oceanic and redemption-themed lyrics, earning praise for its hymnal, stadium-ready grandeur. A Clams Casino remix and Karl Lagerfeld-shot vinyl artwork added collector appeal, while an ice-rink music video starring Jamie Campbell Bower amplified its gothic, water-soaked aesthetic. Despite modest UK chart success, the song became the band’s highest-charting single in Australia (peaking at #3) and was later certified Gold in Britain. After heavy rotation on the 2011–12 *Ceremonials Tour*, Welch briefly retired it, only to revive it during the 2022 and 2026 tours.  

**Keywords**: Florence and the Machine, baroque-pop ballad, Clams Casino remix, ice-rink music video, *Ceremonials* single

**Title**: Steven Landsburg Controversies  

**Summary**:  
Economics professor Steven Landsburg repeatedly sparked public backlash through provocative blog posts and media commentary. In 2012 he defended Rush Limbaugh’s slur against student Sandra Fluke, later calling Fluke an “extortionist,” prompting student protests and a rebuke from his university president. A year later he used a hypothetical justification of raping an unconscious victim to critique a libertarian legal principle, triggering petitions, classroom protests, and national media coverage. These incidents cemented his reputation as an outspoken, controversy-courting academic.  

**Keywords**:  
Steven Landsburg, University of Rochester, Sandra Fluke controversy, rape analogy backlash, libertarian provocateur

**Title**: Róisín Murphy Solo Career

**Summary**:  
After the breakup of Moloko, Róisín Murphy launched a solo career marked by artistic independence and experimental electronic-pop. Her debut album *Ruby Blue* (2005), produced with Matthew Herbert, fused everyday sound samples with jazz-pop and earned critical praise despite commercial underperformance. The 2007 follow-up *Overpowered* leaned toward dance-pop, supported by singles like “Overpowered” and “Let Me Know.” Following an eight-year hiatus punctuated by guest appearances, Murphy returned with the Mercury-nominated *Hairless Toys* (2015) and its companion *Take Her Up to Monto* (2016). Continuing her collaboration with producer Maurice Fulton, she released the acclaimed albums *Róisín Machine* (2020) and *Hit Parade* (2023), cementing her reputation for sophisticated, emotionally layered electronic music.

**Title**: Brady Seals Career Overview

**Summary**: Brady Seals is an American country music artist who began his career in 1988 as co-lead vocalist and keyboardist for the band Little Texas, contributing to all their major hits until 1994. After departing Little Texas, he launched a solo career, releasing three studio albums between 1996 and 2003, including his only solo Top 40 hit "Another You, Another Me." In 2002, he formed the quartet Hot Apple Pie, which charted three singles including "Hillbillies," and released his fourth solo album "Play Time" in 2009. Raised in a musical family in Fairfield, Ohio, Seals started playing piano at age nine and comes from a family of notable musicians including cousins Jim Seals and Dan Seals.

**Title:** Vince Guaraldi Jazz Legacy

**Summary:**  
Vince Guaraldi was an influential American jazz pianist and composer whose career spanned from the 1950s to the 1970s. He gained mainstream recognition with his 1962 Grammy-winning hit "Cast Your Fate to the Wind" and became widely known for composing the iconic music for *A Charlie Brown Christmas* and other *Peanuts* specials. Guaraldi frequently performed in trio configurations, collaborating with notable musicians such as Eddie Duran, Monty Budwig, and Jerry Granelli. His work blended jazz, bossa nova, and Latin influences, and he was a key figure in Cal Tjader’s ensembles during the late 1950s.

**Keywords:**  
Vince Guaraldi, jazz pianist, Peanuts soundtrack, Cast Your Fate to the Wind, Cal Tjader

**Title**: Brady Seals Debut Album  

**Summary**:  
“The Truth” is country artist Brady Seals’ first solo album after departing the band Little Texas, released on Reprise Records in February 1997. The project produced three singles—“Another You, Another Me,” “Still Standing Tall,” and “Natural Born Lovers”—with only the first reaching the Top 40 on Hot Country Songs. Seals co-produced the record with Rodney Crowell, assembling a roster of Nashville A-list musicians and technical staff that lend polished instrumentation and rich arrangements across the track list.

**Keywords**:  
Brady Seals, The Truth album, country music debut, Reprise Records, Hot Country Songs

**Title**: Jaguar R2 F1 Season

**Summary**: The Jaguar R2 was the Formula One car used by Jaguar in the 2001 season, driven by Eddie Irvine and initially Luciano Burti, later replaced by Pedro de la Rosa. The season marked a modest improvement over 2000, with the team scoring nine points and achieving their first podium at Monaco. Off-track drama included a failed attempt to hire designer Adrian Newey and the eventual replacement of team principal Bobby Rahal by Niki Lauda. The R2 was the last F1 car to use Texaco fuel and featured minor livery updates, including tributes post-9/11.

**Keywords**: Jaguar R2, 2001 Formula One, Eddie Irvine, Niki Lauda, Monaco podium

**Title**: 2001 Monaco Grand Prix Drama  

**Summary**:  
Michael Schumacher dominated the 2001 Monaco Grand Prix, setting a new lap record and securing his fourth win of the season amid high attrition that saw only ten of 22 starters finish. The race was marked by a tense 35-lap feud between McLaren’s David Coulthard and Arrows’ Enrique Bernoldi, whose defensive driving triggered post-race threats from McLaren management and driver-association complaints. Multiple retirements—Panis, Häkkinen, Trulli, Fisichella, Frentzen and others—shuffled the order and promoted Jaguar’s Eddie Irvine to the team’s first podium in third place. Ferrari’s one-two finish extended Schumacher’s championship lead to 12 points and the team’s constructors’ cushion to 32.  

**Keywords**: Monaco Grand Prix 2001, Schumacher victory, Coulthard-Bernoldi feud, high attrition, Irvine podium

**Title:** Count Basie’s Legacy and Collaborations  

**Summary:**  
Count Basie, a pioneering jazz pianist and bandleader, sustained the Big Band era by collaborating with iconic vocalists such as Ella Fitzgerald, Frank Sinatra, Joe Williams, and Tony Bennett, producing landmark albums from the 1950s through the 1970s. His orchestra, noted for the “New Testament” band sound, featured arrangements by Quincy Jones, Neal Hefti, and Sammy Nestico, yielding Grammy-winning and Hall-of-Fame recordings. Basie’s later life was marked by personal losses—his wife Catherine in 1983 and his own death to pancreatic cancer in 1984—yet his influence endures through honors including the Presidential Medal of Freedom, a U.S. postage stamp, and multiple inductions into music Halls of Fame.  

**Keywords:**  
Count Basie, Big Band jazz, Ella Fitzgerald, Frank Sinatra, Grammy Hall of Fame

**Title**: 2001 Monaco Grand Prix Technical Updates

**Summary**:  
Ahead of the 2001 Monaco Grand Prix, teams introduced extensive aerodynamic and safety upgrades—Prost, Benetton, and Jaguar revised wings, undertrays, and crash structures, while Arrows and Jordan debuted elevated nose-wing devices that were later banned for regulatory infringement. Practice sessions saw dry conditions and multiple incidents, with Häkkinen ultimately setting the fastest lap. Championship leader Michael Schumacher, after inheriting pole from Coulthard’s stalled car, dominated the race to secure his fourth win of the season and extend Ferrari’s Constructors’ lead. Concerns over electronic launch-control reliability prompted Jordan to revert to manual starts, and the FIA warned of severe penalties for mis-configured systems.

**Keywords**: Monaco Grand Prix 2001, aerodynamic upgrades, launch control, Michael Schumacher, FIA regulations

**Title**: University of Rochester Controversies and Growth

**Summary**:  
The University of Rochester faced a major sexual harassment scandal beginning in 2017, when eight faculty members filed an EEOC complaint alleging misconduct and administrative cover-up, leading to a $9.4 million lawsuit settlement in 2020 and the resignation of President Joel Seligman. Despite this, the accused faculty member remains employed. Amid ongoing campus protests and disciplinary actions related to the Israel–Hamas war, the university continues significant expansion, including a $50 million gift for a new intellectual disabilities institute, major medical center upgrades, and acquisition of College Town, underscoring its trajectory of growth alongside governance challenges.

**Keywords**:  
sexual harassment scandal, campus protests, medical expansion, Golisano donation, leadership changes

**Title**: 1997 Argentine Grand Prix

**Summary**: The 1997 Argentine Grand Prix, the 600th World Championship race, was won from pole by Jacques Villeneuve, with Eddie Irvine second and rookie Ralf Schumacher taking his first podium in third. The event was marked by multiple first-lap collisions that triggered a Safety Car and eliminated several front-runners, including Michael Schumacher and David Coulthard. Mid-field battles saw Pedro Diniz surge from last to 11th, while both Jordan drivers retired with engine failures after strong runs. Post-race controversy arose when organizers flew the Irish tricolour for Northern Irish driver Irvine, prompting loyalist backlash and FIA insistence on future use of the Union Jack.

**Keywords**: 1997 Argentine GP, Jacques Villeneuve, Eddie Irvine, Ralf Schumacher, podium controversy
